climbs.name: Wise Guys
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Kelly Vaught, and Frank Bentwood, August 1999

content.description:
This very unique pitch climbs the chimney to reach the overhanging face/arete on the inside face of the pinnacle.

Start from Paisano Ledge. Stem up the chimney behind the pinnacle. As it widens, a full-body stem is required to reach holds on the face of the pinnacle.

Once comitted to the face, crank bouldery moves around the overhanging arete (5.12-), then climb the very delicate (5.12b) outer face to the top.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2-bolt belay/rappel anchor (80 ft. rap)

climbs.name: Superfly
climbs.fa: Bill Antel, Mike Graham, Tobin Sorenson, and Eric Accomazzo

content.description: This climb is truly unique.  Its rating is anybody's guess.  From the top of Paisano Pinnacle, walk down to the very edge, looking out over the slot that separates the pinnacle from the nearby wall.  Make a long jump over to the sloping wall, and then climb up 5.6 friction to the top.  Your belayer has to give you a lot of slack to let you do the jump, and you would get scraped up if you didn't stick the landing.  Tobin Sorenson once did the leap with a full twist.
content.protection: None, but your belayer is above you (on top of the pinnacle) when you make the jump.

climbs.name: The Step Away
climbs.fa: Charlie Raymond and Pat Callis, November 1966

content.description: This is the easiest route to the top of Paisano Pinnacle.  From Paisano Ledge, walk back into the slot behind the pinnacle, and then chimney up and right.  Eventually you reach a thin crack high on the southwest corner.  Exciting, exposed wide stemming and face climbing take you a short distance up to the top.  Once you figure out the moves, they aren't difficult to do.  The protection is fair.  This climb may be more difficult for shorter climbers.

climbs.name: Skigliak
climbs.fa: Dave Hanbury and Dave Black, July 1971

content.description: This face route is between Mushy Peach and Continuation, on the wall behind Paisano Pinnacle. After the crux, you can either move left to the rappel bolts (making the pitch 100' or less), or continue straight to the top of the rock (160' pitch).

Sweet diversion. Start from the east or west side of Paisano Pinnacle and traverse under the roof, passing under Paisano Overhang. If going east to west will require a leap at the end on to the top of a block with two bolts for a rap. Same rap as Clockwork Orange. Or, climb back behind the Pinnacle and top out via Eyes Wide Shut.
content.location: Start on Paisano Ledge or do Paisano Chimney (5.8) or Clockwork Orange (5.10d) first on the west side.

climbs.name: Paisano Jam Crack
climbs.fa: Mark Powell, Don Wilson, and Frank Hoover, February 1955

content.description: This is apparently the earliest recorded climb at Suicide Rock.  The first ascent party brought a jug of Paisano with them, and left the empty bottle on top of the pinnacle.  It's a short, clean 4" wide offwidth.  From Paisano ledge, walk into the slot behind the pinnacle, and you will see this route on your left.
This one pitch, balancy face route starts on Paisano Ledge, and goes up to the top of the rock.  A good spot is useful before you get to the first bolt.

climbs.name: Mantle of No Return
climbs.fa: Jim Wilson, Gib Lewis, and Kyle Cooper, October 1973

content.description: The end of this route is lower than the start.  From the top of the rock, scramble down to the rappel bolts above Paisano Ledge and set up a belay.  Climb down the steepening face until you can bridge across to the lip of the pinnacle.  A few wild, exposed face moves take you up onto the pinnacle and on to the bolt anchor on top.

climbs.name: Paisano Overhang
climbs.fa: Pat Callis & Charlie Raymond, January 1968,  FFA: John Long, 1973

content.description:
The Paisano Overhang is a 4" to 6" offwidth 20 foot roof crack on Paisano pinnacle atop the Sunshine Face on the front side of Paisano jam crack. The crux is definitely the lip the last 6 to 8 feet of the roof go beyond inverted with MAX exposure high above the Sunshine Face.

youtube.com/watch?v=fu7gp-aâ€¦
content.protection: Large cams 4 to 6 inches, bolt anchors

climbs.name: Eyes Wide Shut
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Kelly Vaught & Frank Bentwood, September 1999

content.description: A great way to finish Paisano Chimney, can also be approached from Paisano ledge. A wide stem on the west side of the Paisano chimney leads to one bolt, clip, surmount the ledge then traverse across to the arete for one more bolt to the top. Rappel off.
content.protection: Two bolts but it's not a sport climb.
content.location: Do Paisano Chimney to this or approch from Paisano Ledge (east side), squeeze behind Paisano Pinnacle and look for a bolt on the left.

content.description: A delicate slab with the crux coming at the second bolt where climbing straight up yields a 5.11b and moving right is a bit easier at 5.10C. The route continues up easy slab to anchors.
content.location:
Located just left of

Paisano Jam Crack

.

content.description: This route is used mainly as an easy way to get to the top of the rock from Paisano Ledge.  The climbing is easy except for one face move by a bolt.  Above the bolt, there is a 60 foot runout on 4th and easy 5th class rock.
content.protection: one bolt and a mix of small to medium gear
